abstract: The British Broadcasting Corporation said that it was in discussions with Google about putting some of the BBC’s programming on the online video site YouTube. A BBC spokeswoman confirmed the talks but said a deal had not been signed. YouTube, which was acquired by Google in October for $1.65 billion, has been approaching broadcasters and other owners of copyrighted material to arrange for the site to carry more authorized material.

lead_paragraph: The British Broadcasting Corporation said that it was in discussions with Google about putting some of the BBC’s programming on the online video site YouTube. A BBC spokeswoman confirmed the talks but said a deal had not been signed. YouTube, which was acquired by Google in October for $1.65 billion, has been approaching broadcasters and other owners of copyrighted material to arrange for the site to carry more authorized material.

headline.main: Britain: BBC in Talks With YouTube
headline.print_headline: Britain: Bbc in Talks With Youtube

abstract: The World Economic Forum in Davos has yet to start and already reports are surfacing about the first deal to be announced there. The Guardian wrote Monday that the British Broadcasting Company was in talks with Google to make programming available through a branded channel on YouTube, the video site the Internet giant bought last year for $1.65 billion.
lead_paragraph: The World Economic Forum in Davos has yet to start and already reports are surfacing about the first deal to be announced there. The Guardian wrote Monday that the British Broadcasting Company was in talks with Google to make programming available through a branded channel on YouTube, the video site the Internet giant bought last year for $1.65 billion.

headline.main: Davos in the Papers: Google, Trade Talks, Dark Rooms

abstract: Regulators should hold off on ruling how the New York Stock Exchange charges for its market data until questions about its new status as a for-profit group are resolved, the Securities Industry and Financial Markets association, a Wall Street lobbying group, has asked. The NYSE Group, which owns the exchange, is preparing to charge fees for access to ArcaBook, the real-time market data system the exchange picked up when it merged with Archipelago Holdings last year. Among the offerings the market is planning is real-time share-price data to Web sites like Google and CNBC, in return for a flat fee.
lead_paragraph: Regulators should hold off on ruling how the New York Stock Exchange charges for its market data until questions about its new status as a for-profit group are resolved, the Securities Industry and Financial Markets association, a Wall Street lobbying group, has asked. headline.main: Lobbyists Ask for Delay on N.Y.S.E. Data Fees Ruling

abstract: As politicians and moguls stream into Davos, some of them arrive with a discreet black envelope in their luggage. It contains an invitation to what has consistently been one of the conference’s hottest events: the party hosted by Web search giant Google.
lead_paragraph: As politicians and moguls stream into Davos, some of them arrive with a discreet black envelope in their luggage. It contains an invitation to what has consistently been one of the conference’s hottest events: the party hosted by Web search giant Google.
